issue.title: pytest: test very long urls

repository.name: curl
repository.description: A command line tool and library for transferring data with URL syntax, supporting DICT, FILE, FTP, FTPS, GOPHER, GOPHERS, HTTP, HTTPS, IMAP, IMAPS, LDAP, LDAPS, MQTT, POP3, POP3S, RTMP, RTMPS, RTSP, SCP, SFTP, SMB, SMBS, SMTP, SMTPS, TELNET, TFTP, WS and WSS. libcurl offers a myriad of powerful features

issue.body:
test_02_36 tests h1/h2/h3 with urls longer than 1/16/32/64K.

Protocols behave the same until the size exceed 64k when h2 frame limits bite and h3 exhibits a different http status.

refs #18121

body:
@adamse, thanks for the report. I added tests for super-sized URLs in #18129:

With url lenghts less than 64KB, all protocols work and behave the same. When crossing 64KB, things start to differ:

* http/1.1: works the same, Apache httpd gives HTTP response 414
* h2: fails sending the request due to protocol limitations that cannot send headers that do not fit in a frame
* h3: gives HTTP response 431 from nghttpx (this might vary with other servers)

So, in these tests, curl works just as intended. The h2 limitations are just inherent to the protocol.

Now, in your failures, was HTTP/2 used?
This is http/1.1 over TLS (using openssl).
We are setting `SSL_MODE_ACCEPT_MOVING_WRITE_BUFFER` when available. That should work with the OpenSSL 3.4.1 you are using. Trying to reproduce here...
(My original url was 135K but I bisected the url to around 64K)

> We are setting SSL_MODE_ACCEPT_MOVING_WRITE_BUFFER when available

I agree, I can see that line being executed in the debugger.

I've simulated partial/blocked writes and my tests run just fine with OpenSSL 3.4.1. 

Since I am unable to reproduce, it would help if you could produce a trace, using `curl_global_trace("all")` and a `DEBUGFUNCTION`. Also, a `curl_global_init()` would be nice, just to be sure.

Part of the trace:

```
== Info: using HTTP/1.x
== Info: [TCP] send(len=16406) -> 16406, err=0
== Info: [SSL] ossl_bio_cf_out_write(len=16406) -> 16406, err=0
== Info: [TCP] send(len=16406) -> 16406, err=0
== Info: [SSL] ossl_bio_cf_out_write(len=16406) -> 16406, err=0
== Info: [TCP] send(len=16406) -> 16406, err=0
== Info: [SSL] ossl_bio_cf_out_write(len=16406) -> 16406, err=0
== Info: [TCP] send(len=16406) -> 16406, err=0
== Info: [SSL] ossl_bio_cf_out_write(len=16406) -> 16406, err=0
== Info: [TCP] send(len=16406) -> -1, err=81
== Info: [SSL] ossl_bio_cf_out_write(len=16406) -> -1, err=81
== Info: SSL_write() error: error:0A00010F:SSL routines::bad length
== Info: [WRITE] cw-out done
```

(DEBUGFUNCTION like the example on https://curl.se/libcurl/c/CURLOPT_DEBUGFUNCTION.html (except the dump part, with dump I don't see the error, I'm guessing dumping the bytes makes it slow enough that we don't hit this SSL_write error)).

I also added `curl_global_init(CURL_GLOBAL_ALL);`.

Thanks. Here is what I see using curl 8.12.1 and OpenSSL 3.4.1:

```
13:24:44.070259 [0-0] * using HTTP/1.x
13:24:44.070328 [0-0] * STATE: CONNECTING => PROTOCONNECT handle 0x7fede501b008; line 2447
13:24:44.070399 [0-0] * STATE: PROTOCONNECT => DO handle 0x7fede501b008; line 2477
13:24:44.073269 [0-0] * sending last upload chunk of 65636 bytes
13:24:44.073350 [0-0] } [5 bytes data]
13:24:44.073472 [0-0] * [TCP] send(len=16406) -> 16406, err=0
13:24:44.073544 [0-0] * [SSL] ossl_bio_cf_out_write(len=16406) -> 16406, err=0
13:24:44.073617 [0-0] } [5 bytes data]
13:24:44.073733 [0-0] * [TCP] send(len=16406) -> 16406, err=0
13:24:44.073804 [0-0] * [SSL] ossl_bio_cf_out_write(len=16406) -> 16406, err=0
13:24:44.073876 [0-0] } [5 bytes data]
13:24:44.073985 [0-0] * [TCP] send(len=16406) SIMULATE EWOULDBLOCK
13:24:44.074053 [0-0] * [SSL] ossl_bio_cf_out_write(len=16406) -> -1, err=81
13:24:44.074124 [0-0] * Curl_xfer_send(len=65636, eos=1) -> 0, 0
13:24:44.074237 [0-0] * [TCP] send(len=16406) SIMULATE EWOULDBLOCK
13:24:44.074307 [0-0] * [SSL] ossl_bio_cf_out_write(len=16406) -> -1, err=81
13:24:44.074375 [0-0] * Curl_xfer_send(len=65536, eos=0) -> 0, 0
13:24:44.074443 [0-0] * Curl_req_flush(len=65636) -> EAGAIN
```

This looks like exactly the same network condition, only for me OpenSSL does not report a bad length.

Ok, that's interesting...


Some ad-hoc logging in `ossl_send`
```
printf("SSL_write(%p, %p, %zu)\n", octx->ssl, mem, memlen);
```

```
== Info: using HTTP/1.x
SSL_write(0x22e20e57130, 0x22e21237350, 137998)
== Info: [TCP] send(len=16406) -> 16406, err=0
== Info: [SSL] ossl_bio_cf_out_write(len=16406) -> 16406, err=0
== Info: [TCP] send(len=16406) -> 16406, err=0
== Info: [SSL] ossl_bio_cf_out_write(len=16406) -> 16406, err=0
== Info: [TCP] send(len=16406) -> 16406, err=0
== Info: [SSL] ossl_bio_cf_out_write(len=16406) -> 16406, err=0
== Info: [TCP] send(len=16406) -> 16406, err=0
== Info: [SSL] ossl_bio_cf_out_write(len=16406) -> 16406, err=0
== Info: [TCP] send(len=16406) -> -1, err=81
== Info: [SSL] ossl_bio_cf_out_write(len=16406) -> -1, err=81
SSL_write(0x22e20e57130, 0x22e21277380, 65536)
== Info: SSL_write() error: error:0A00010F:SSL routines::bad length
== Info: [WRITE] cw-out done
```


so, I go back to the initial thought: SSL_write doesn't get the same buf (which in curl's case might be moved) and length after `SSL_ERROR_WANT_WRITE`...

issue.title: openssl: check SSL_write() length on retries

repository.name: curl
repository.description: A command line tool and library for transferring data with URL syntax, supporting DICT, FILE, FTP, FTPS, GOPHER, GOPHERS, HTTP, HTTPS, IMAP, IMAPS, LDAP, LDAPS, MQTT, POP3, POP3S, RTMP, RTMPS, RTSP, SCP, SFTP, SMB, SMBS, SMTP, SMTPS, TELNET, TFTP, WS and WSS. libcurl offers a myriad of powerful features

issue.body:
When an SSL_write() blocks we need to retry it with the same length as before or stupid OpenSSL freaks out. Remember it, limit any longer sends and fail shorter ones.

refs #18121

body:
Then you managed to trigger a retrying send with a larger buffer length. Can you try #18132 in your setup?

This is really annoying from OpenSSL that it does not accept a longer length the second time - assuming the PR works for you.
I end up hitting `CURLE_BAD_FUNCTION_ARGUMENT` with that change.
I need a full trace of what you are doing, not just the excerpts then.

[trace.txt](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/21549254/trace.txt)

Program is still the same, url length is 137972 bytes.

So, you sneakily made the URLs even longer. Tststs.

But thanks to your efforts, I found the bug in request sending that led to shorter sends on retries. Fix in #18132 now.

Sorry, I should've been clearer about the full url length from the start, not just the smallest that failed! :)

I can confirm things seem to work with the latest #18132 !
